author: RICK GLADSTONE
title: Coincidence or Message? A Timeline of Provocative Acts by North Korea

organizations.name: credit stephen crowley/the new york times  advertisement continue

text:
Continue reading the main story Photo The launching of a long-range ballistic missile was broadcast in Pyongyang on Feb. 13. Credit Kim Won-Jin/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images North Korea is well known for provocative acts aimed at its most immediate adversaries — South Korea, the United States and Japan. But Kim Jong-un , the 33-year-old leader who took over in 2012 after his father died, also has sent increasingly blunt messages of defiance and even hostility to China, the North’s ally, protector and provider, vexing the Chinese as well. Based on their timing, the North Korean actions — whether they be a missile launch, nuclear test, execution or propaganda campaign — often seem like more than coincidence. Here is a sampling from the past decade: A July 4 missile launch As the United States celebrated Independence Day in 2006, North Korea test-fired seven ballistic missiles including the Taepo Dong 2, its longest-range missile, in what the State Department called a provocative act. Photo South Korean marines patrolled along the coast of Yeonpyeong Island in 2010 after it was shelled by North Korea. Credit David Guttenfelder/Associated Press Shelling after a summit meeting On Nov. 23, 2010, less than two weeks after South Korea hosted a Group of 20 summit meeting, North Korea fired dozens of artillery shells onto a South Korean island, killing two soldiers and setting more than 60 houses on fire. A nuclear test amid Lunar New Year celebrations On Feb. 11 , 2013, less than two weeks after the United Nations Security Council expanded sanctions on North Korea for a satellite launch, and in the midst of China’s Lunar New Year holiday, North Korea confirmed it had conducted its third nuclear test. Photo Kim Jong-un, second from left, toured the newly opened Fatherland Liberation War Museum in Pyongyang with his uncle Jang Song-thaek, right, in 2013. Months later, Mr. Jang was executed after being convicted of treason. Credit Wong Maye-E/Associated Press An execution follows outreach to China On Dec. 12, 2013, North Korea announced the execution of Jang Song-thaek, Mr. Kim’s uncle and mentor, who was considered close to China and had actively sought advice from Chinese leaders on economic matters. Mr. Jang was accused of treason and corruption. 
Advertisement Continue reading the main story Midrange missiles are launched after three-way talks On March 25 , 2014 , North Korea tested two midrange missiles, the first such launch in five years, hours after the United States, South Korea and Japan held an extraordinary three-way summit meeting to discuss the North’s nuclear buildup. Photo A military parade was held for the 70th anniversary of the end of World War II in Beijing in 2015. Credit Damir Sagolj/Reuters China snubs Kim, and good-will concerts are canceled On Sept. 3, 2015, China he ld a grand celebration on the 70th anniversary of Japan’s defeat in World War II, and Kim Jong-un was conspicuously not on the guest list, which included South Korea’s president at the time, Park Geun-hye, whom Mr. Kim openly despised. Two months later, concerts in China by an all-girl pop band from North Korea that had been intended to improve relations were abruptly canceled . Photo President Barack Obama, left, and President Xi Jinping of China, opposite on right, at a Group of 20 summit meeting last year in Hangzhou, China. Less than a week later, North Korea conducted its fifth and most powerful nuclear test. Credit Stephen Crowley/The New York Times 
Advertisement Continue reading the main story Nuclear tests bookend holidays and talks On Feb. 6 , 2016, as China prepared to celebrate the Lunar New Year, North Korea launched a long-range ballistic missile carrying what it described as an observation satellite, in defiance of United Nations sanctions. On Sept. 8 of that year, less than a week after China hosted a Group of 20 summit meeting in Hangzhou, North Korea conducted its fifth and most powerful nuclear test. Photo Graffiti referring to Kim Jong-nam in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia. Mr. Kim, Kim Jong-un’s estranged half-brother, was assassinated at Kuala Lumpur International Airport last month. Credit Mohd Rasfan/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images 
Advertisement Continue reading the main story A flurry of provocations after Trump settles in North Korea tested an intermediate-range missile on Feb. 11, while President Trump was hosting Prime Minister Shinzo Abe of Japan at Mr. Trump’s Mar-a-Lago club in Florida. The missile used solid fuel, which disarmament experts called a significant advance. A few days later, Mr. Kim’s estranged older half brother, Kim Jong-nam , who had been living in exile under China’s protection, was assassinated at an airport in Malaysia. His death came amid rumors that China might have been preparing him to take over in case North Korea’s government collapsed. North Korea denied responsibility. On March 20 , North Korea tested a revved-up rocket engine, a few days after Secretary of State Rex W. Tillerson warned in South Korea that the Trump administration might take pre-emptive military action if the North Koreans elevated “the threat of their weapons program” to a level deemed unacceptable.
